Mathematical expectation of discrete random variables
This is the start of Chapter 4 in Freund's Mathematical Statistics. In the first pass we will study the major topics of this chapter with a focus on those applying to discrete random variables.
Expected value
See section 4.1 - 4.2. Recommended problems: (pg 136) 7, 9, 10, 11, (pg 161) 60
expected value
If X is a discrete random variable and \displaystyle f(x) is the value of its probability distribution at X, the expected value of X is given by E[X] = \sum_x x\cdot f(x)
expected value of a random variable
Recall the function f(x) = \dfrac{2x-1}{25} from , which is a probability mass function for the discrete random variable X with values x=1,2,3,4,5. Find \mu = E[X]
Since \mu = E[X], we have
\mu = E[X] \amp = \sum\limits_{x=1}^5 x\cdot f(x) \amp = \sum\limits_{x=1}^5 x\cdot \left(\dfrac{2x-1}{25}\right) \amp = \sum\limits_{x=1}^5 \left(\dfrac{2}{25}x^2 - \dfrac{1}{25}x\right) \amp = \left(\dfrac{2}{25}\sum\limits_{x=1}^5 x^2\right) - \left(\dfrac{1}{25}\sum\limits_{x=1}^5 x\right) \amp = \left(\dfrac{2}{25}\left(55\right)\right) - \left(\dfrac{1}{25}\left(15\right)\right) \mu = E[X] \amp = \dfrac{19}{5}
So, the mean of the distribution of the random variable X is \mu = E[X] = \dfrac{19}{6}.
expected value of a function of a random variable
If X is a discrete random variable and \displaystyle f(x) is the value of its probability distribution at X, the expected value of \displaystyle g(X) is given by E[g(X)] = \sum_x g(x)\cdot f(x)
expectation of a linear function
If \displaystyle a and \displaystyle b are constants, then \displaystyle E[aX +b] = aE[X]+b.
If a is a constant, then \displaystyle E[aX] = aE[X].
If b is a constant, then \displaystyle E[b] = b.
Problem 4.9
Suppose that X takes on values 0, 1, 2, 3 with probabilities \dfrac{1}{125}, \dfrac{12}{125}, \dfrac{48}{125}, \dfrac{64}{125}
Find E[X] and E[X^2]
Determine the value of E[(3X + 2)^2]
Expected value
See section 4.3. Recommended problems: 4.3 (pg 146) 20, 22, 23, 31, 33, 34, 40, (pg 162) 69, 73, 75
moments about the origin
The \displaystyle r^\text{th} moment about the origin of a random variable X, denoted by \displaystyle \mu_r', is the expected value of \displaystyle (X)^r; symbolically \mu_r'=E[(X)^r] = \sum_x x^r\cdot f(x) for \displaystyle r = 0,1,2, \dots when X is discrete.
mean of a discrete random variable
\displaystyle \mu_1' is called the mean of the distribution of X, or simply the mean of X; and it is denoted by \displaystyle \mu.
moments about the mean
The \displaystyle r^\text{th} moment about the mean of a random variable X, denoted by \displaystyle \mu_r, is the expected value of \displaystyle (X-\mu)^r; symbolically \mu_r=E[(X-\mu)^r] = \sum_x (x-\mu)^r\cdot f(x) for \displaystyle r = 0,1,2, \dots when X is discrete.
variance of a random variable
Recall the function f(x) = \dfrac{2x-1}{25} from and , which is a probability mass function for the discrete random variable X with values x=1,2,3,4,5. Find \sigma^2 = \mu_{2} = E[(X - \mu)^2]
Recall that \sigma^2 = \mu_{2}' - \left(E[x]\right)^2 or \sigma^2 = E[X^2] - \left(E[x]\right)^2. Since \mu_{2}' = E[X^2], we have
\mu_{2}' = E[X^2] \amp = \sum\limits_{x=1}^5 x^2\cdot f(x) \amp = \sum\limits_{x=1}^5 x^2\cdot \left(\dfrac{2x-1}{25}\right) \amp = \sum\limits_{x=1}^5 \left(\dfrac{2}{25}x^3 - \dfrac{1}{25}x^2\right) \amp = \left(\dfrac{2}{25}\sum\limits_{x=1}^5 x^3\right) - \left(\dfrac{1}{25}\sum\limits_{x=1}^5 x^2\right) \amp = \left(\dfrac{2}{25}\left(225\right)\right) - \left(\dfrac{1}{25}\left(55\right)\right) \mu_{2}' = E[X^2] \amp = \dfrac{79}{25}
Now, by theorem,
\sigma^2 = \amp E[X^2] - \left(E[x]\right)^2 = \amp \dfrac{79}{5} - \left(\dfrac{19}{5}\right)^2 \sigma^2 = \amp \dfrac{34}{25}
Now, you could imagine in some cases the moments being difficult to calculate as sums. We sometimes take the approach of building what are called moment-generating functions. These are mathematical functions whose purpose is to generate the moments of a distribution that we might need.
Problem 4.18
Find \mu, \mu_2', and \sigma^2 for the random variable X that has probability distribution f(x) = 0.5 \text{ for } x= \pm 2.
Moment-generating functions
See section 4.5.
moment-generating function
The moment-generating function of a random variable X, where it exists, is given by \displaystyle M_X(t) = E[e^{tX}] = \sum_x e^{tx}\cdot f(x) when X is discrete.
Notce that a moment-generating function \displaystyle M_X(t) itself is a function of the variable \displaystyle t not X. As it turns out, we are most interested in values of the function at or near \displaystyle t=0.
moment-generating function via Taylor series
Recall that the Maclaurin series (Taylor series around zero) for \displaystyle e^{tx} is e^{tx} = 1 + tx + \frac{1}{2!}\left(tx\right)^2 + \frac{1}{3!}\left(tx\right)^3 + \cdots + \frac{1}{r!}\left(tx\right)^r + \cdots This means (in the discrete case), that \begin{aligned}[t] M_X(t) \amp = \sum_x e^{tx} f(x)\\ \amp = \sum_x \left(1 + tx + \frac{1}{2!}(tx)^2 + \frac{1}{3!}\left(tx\right)^3 + \cdots + \frac{1}{r!}\left(tx\right)^r + \cdots\right) f(x)\\ \amp = \sum_x (f(x) + txf(x) + \frac{t^2}{2!}x^2f(x) + \frac{t^3}{3!}x^3f(x) + \cdots + \frac{t^r}{r!}x^rf(x) + \cdots)\\ \amp = \sum_xf(x) + t\sum_x xf(x) + \frac{t^2}{2!}\sum_x x^2f(x) + \frac{t^3}{3!}\sum_x x^3f(x) + \cdots + \frac{t^r}{r!}\sum_x x^rf(x) + \cdots \end{aligned}
Looking closely, at M_X(t) = \sum_xf(x) + \left(\sum_x xf(x)\right)t + \left(\sum_x x^2f(x)\right)\frac{t^2}{2!} + \left(\sum_x x^3f(x)\right)\frac{t^3}{3!} + \cdots + \left(\sum_x x^rf(x)\right)\frac{t^r}{r!} + \cdots coefficients of the terms \displaystyle \dfrac{t^r}{r!} are the moments about the origin \displaystyle \mu_r' = \sum_x x^r f(x)
moment-generating function for three coins
Recall the probability distribution f(x) = P(X = x) = \dfrac{{3\choose x}}{8} \text{ for } x = 0, 1, 2, 3 (this was used earlier to determine the probabilities of x heads on three flips of a coin).
\begin{aligned}[t] M_X(t) \amp = \sum_x e^{tx} f(x)\\ \amp = 1 \cdot \frac{1}{8} + e^{t} \cdot \frac{3}{8}+ e^{2t} \cdot \frac{3}{8} + e^{3t} \cdot \frac{1}{8}\\ \amp = \frac{1}{8} \left(1 + 3e^{t} + 3e^{2t} + e^{3t}\right)\\ M_X(t) \amp = \frac{1}{8} (1+e^t)^3\\ \end{aligned}
moments via differentiation
The r^\text{th} moment about the origin, \mu_r', can be written \displaystyle \mu_r' = \dfrac{d^rM_X(t)}{dt^r}\Big|_{t=0}
moment-generating function for three cards, via differentiation
Referencing , the mean of the random variable, given by \mu_1', whose MGF is M_X(t) = \frac{1}{8} (1+e^t)^3 is found as follows
\begin{aligned}[t] \mu_1' \amp = \left(\dfrac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{1}{8} (1+e^t)^3\right)\right)\Big|_{t=0}\\ \amp = \left(\frac{3}{8} (1+e^t)^2e^t\right)\Big|_{t=0}\\ \amp = \left(\frac{3}{8} (2)^2\right)\\ \mu_1' \amp = \frac{3}{2} \end{aligned}
So, given a moment-generating function, a relatively simple application of calculus allows us to replace a more tedious calculation of the moment from its definition.
moment-generating function of functions of a random variable
If \displaystyle a and \displaystyle b are constants, then
\displaystyle M_{X+a}(t) = E[e^{(X+a)t}] = e^{at} \cdot M_X(t);
\displaystyle M_{bX}(t) = E[e^{bXt}] = M_X(bt);
\displaystyle M_{\frac{X+a}{b}}(t) = E\left[e^{\left(\frac{X+a}{b}\right)t}\right] = e^{(a/b)t} \cdot M_X\left(\frac{t}{b}\right);
The rules in allow us to calculate moment-generating functions of simple functions of a random variable.
Problem 4.33
Find the moment-generating function of the discrete random variable X that has the probability distribution f(x) = 2\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^x \text{ for } x = 1, 2, 3, \dots and use it to determine the values of \mu_1' and \mu_2'.

Given the moment-generating function X_X(t) = e^{3t+8t^2}, find the moment generating function of the random variable Z = \dfrac{1}{4}\left(X-3\right) and use it to determine the mean and variance of Z.
